scenes.location: Antioch. A room in the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Young prince of Tyre, you have at large received The danger of the task you undertake.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I have, Antiochus, and, with a soul Emboldened with the glory of her praise, Think death no hazard in this enterprise.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Music! Bring in our daughter, clothed like a bride, For the embracements even of Jove himself; At whose conception, till Lucina reigned, Nature this dowry gave, to glad her presence, The senate house of planets all did sit, To knit in her their best perfections. Music. Enter the Daughter of Antiochus.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: See where she comes, apparell'd like the spring, Graces her subjects, and her thoughts the king Of every virtue gives renown to men! Her face the book of praises, where is read Nothing but curious pleasures, as from thence Sorrow were ever razed, and testy wrath Could never be her mild companion. You gods that made me man, and sway in love, That have inflamed desire in my breast To taste the fruit of yon celestial tree, Or die in the adventure, be my helps, As I am son and servant to your will, To compass such a boundless happiness!

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Prince Pericles,-

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: That would be son to great Antiochus.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Before thee stands this fair Hesperides, With golden fruit, but dangerous to be touch'd; For death-like dragons here affright thee hard: Her face, like heaven, enticeth thee to view Her countless glory, which desert must gain; And which, without desert, because thine eye Presumes to reach, all the whole heap must die. Yon sometimes famous princes, like thyself, Drawn by report, adventurous by desire, Tell thee, with speechless tongues and semblance pale, That without covering, save yon field of stars, Here they stand Martyrs, slain in Cupid's wars; And with dead cheeks advise thee to desist For going on death's net, whom none resist.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Antiochus, I thank thee, who hath taught My frail mortality to know itself, And by those fearful objects to prepare This body, like to them, to what I must; For death remember'd should be like a mirror, Who tells us life's but breath, to trust it error. I'll make my will then, and, as sick men do Who know the world, see heaven, but, feeling woe, Gripe not at earthly joys as erst they did; So I bequeath a happy peace to you And all good men, as every prince should do; My riches to the earth from whence they came;  But my unspotted fire of love to you. Thus ready for the way of life or death, I wait the sharpest blow, Antiochus.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Scorning advice, read the conclusion, then: Which read and not expounded, 'tis decreed, As these before thee thou thyself shalt bleed.

dialogues.speaker: Daughter
dialogues.line: Of all 'ssayed yet, mayst thou prove prosperous! Of all 'ssayed yet, I wish thee happiness!

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Like a bold champion, I assume the lists, Nor ask advice of any other thought But faithfulness and courage. _I am no viper, yet I feed On mother's flesh which did me breed. I sought a husband, in which labour I found that kindness in a father: He's father, son, and husband mild; I mother, wife, and yet his child. How they may be, and yet in two, As you will live resolve it you._ Sharp physic is the last: but, O you powers That give heaven countless eyes to view men's acts, Why cloud they not their sights perpetually, If this be true, which makes me pale to read it? Fair glass of light, I loved you, and could still, Were not this glorious casket stored with ill: But I must tell you, now my thoughts revolt; For he's no man on whom perfections wait That, knowing sin within, will touch the gate, You are a fair viol, and your sense the strings; Who, finger'd to make man his lawful music, Would draw heaven down, and all the gods to hearken; But being play'd upon before your time, Hell only danceth at so harsh a chime. Good sooth, I care not for you.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Prince Pericles, touch not, upon thy life, For that's an article within our law, As dangerous as the rest. Your time's expired: Either expound now, or receive your sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Great king, Few love to hear the sins they love to act; 'Twould braid yourself too near for me to tell it. Who has a book of all that monarchs do, He's more secure to keep it shut than shown: For vice repeated is like the wandering wind, Blows dust in others' eyes, to spread itself; And yet the end of all is bought thus dear, The breath is gone, and the sore eyes see clear. To stop the air would hurt them. The blind mole casts Copp'd hills towards heaven, to tell the earth is throng'd By man's oppression; and the poor worm doth die for't. Kind are earth's gods; in vice their law's their will; And if Jove stray, who dares say Jove doth ill? It is enough you know; and it is fit, What being more known grows worse, to smother it. All love the womb that their first bred, Then give my tongue like leave to love my head.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Heaven, that I had thy head! He has found the meaning: But I will gloze with him.-Young prince of Tyre. Though by the tenour of our strict edict, Your exposition misinterpreting, We might proceed to cancel of your days; Yet hope, succeeding from so fair a tree As your fair self, doth tune us otherwise: Forty days longer we do respite you; If by which time our secret be undone, This mercy shows we'll joy in such a son: And until then your entertain shall be As doth befit our honour and your worth.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: How courtesy would seem to cover sin, When what is done is like an hypocrite, The which is good in nothing but in sight! If it be true that I interpret false, Then were it certain you were not so bad As with foul incest to abuse your soul; Where now you're both a father and a son, By your untimely claspings with your child, Which pleasures fits a husband, not a father; And she an eater of her mother's flesh, By the defiling of her parent's bed; And both like serpents are, who though they feed On sweetest flowers, yet they poison breed. Antioch, farewell! for wisdom sees, those men Blush not in actions blacker than the night, Will 'schew no course to keep them from the light. One sin, I know, another doth provoke; Murder's as near to lust as flame to smoke: Poison and treason are the hands of sin, Ay, and the targets, to put off the shame: Then, lest my life be cropp'd to keep you clear, By flight I'll shun the danger which I fear.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: He hath found the meaning, For which we mean to have his head. He must not live to trumpet forth my infamy, Nor tell the world Antiochus doth sin In such a loathed manner; And therefore instantly this prince must die; For by his fall my honour must keep high. Who attends us there?

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: Doth your highness call?

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Thaliard, you are of our chamber, And our mind partakes her private actions To your secrecy; and for your faithfulness We will advance you. Thaliard, Behold, here's poison, and here's gold; We hate the prince of Tyre, and thou must kill him: It fits thee not to ask the reason why, Because we bid it. Say, is it done?

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: My lord, 'tis done.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Enough. Let your breath cool yourself, telling your haste.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord, Prince Pericles is fled.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: As thou wilt live, fly after: and like an arrow shot From a well-experienced archer hits the mark His eye doth level at, so thou ne'er return Unless thou say â€˜Prince Pericles is dead.'

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: My lord, if I can get him within my pistol's length, I'll make him sure enough: so, farewell to your highness.

dialogues.speaker: Antiochus
dialogues.line: Thaliard! adieu! Till Pericles be dead, My heart can lend no succour to my head.

scenes.location: Tyre. A room in the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Let none disturb us.-Why should this change of thoughts, The sad companion, dull-eyed melancholy, Be my so used a guest as not an hour In the day's glorious walk or peaceful night, The tomb where grief should sleep, can breed me quiet? Here pleasures court mine eyes, and mine eyes shun them, And danger, which I fear'd, is at Antioch, Whose arm seems far too short to hit me here: Yet neither pleasure's art can joy my spirits, Nor yet the other's distance comfort me. Then it is thus: the passions of the mind, That have their first conception by misdread, Have after-nourishment and life by care; And what was first but fear what might be done, Grows elder now and cares it be not done. And so with me: the great Antiochus, 'Gainst whom I am too little to contend, Since he's so great can make his will his act, Will think me speaking, though I swear to silence; Nor boots it me to say I honour him. If he suspect I may dishonour him: And what may make him blush in being known, He'll stop the course by which it might be known; With hostile forces he'll o'erspread the land, And with the ostent of war will look so huge, Amazement shall drive courage from the state; Our men be vanquish'd ere they do resist, And subjects punish'd that ne'er thought offence: Which care of them, not pity of myself, Who am no more but as the tops of trees, Which fence the roots they grow by and defend them, Makes both my body pine and soul to languish, And punish that before that he would punish.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Joy and all comfort in your sacred breast!

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: And keep your mind, till you return to us, Peaceful and comfortable!

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: Peace, peace, and give experience tongue. They do abuse the king that flatter him: For flattery is the bellows blows up sin; The thing the which is flatter'd, but a spark, To which that spark gives heat and stronger glowing: Whereas reproof, obedient and in order, Fits kings, as they are men, for they may err. When Signior Sooth here does proclaim peace, He flatters you, makes war upon your life. Prince, pardon me, or strike me, if you please; I cannot be much lower than my knees.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: All leave us else, but let your cares o'erlook What shipping and what lading's in our haven, And then return to us. Helicanus, thou Hast moved us: what seest thou in our looks?

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: An angry brow, dread lord.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: If there be such a dart in princes' frowns, How durst thy tongue move anger to our face?

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: How dares the plants look up to heaven, from whence They have their nourishment?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Thou know'st I have power To take thy life from thee. HELICANUS.  I have ground the axe myself; Do but you strike the blow.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Rise, prithee, rise. Sit down: thou art no flatterer: I thank thee for it; and heaven forbid That kings should let their ears hear their faults hid! Fit counsellor and servant for a prince, Who by thy wisdom makest a prince thy servant, What wouldst thou have me do?

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: To bear with patience Such griefs as you yourself do lay upon yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Thou speak'st like a physician, Helicanus, That ministers a potion unto me That thou wouldst tremble to receive thyself. Attend me, then: I went to Antioch, Where, as thou know'st, against the face of death, I sought the purchase of a glorious beauty, From whence an issue I might propagate, Are arms to princes, and bring joys to subjects. Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder; The rest-hark in thine ear-as black as incest, Which by my knowledge found, the sinful father Seem'd not to strike, but smooth: but thou know'st this, 'Tis time to fear when tyrants seems to kiss. Which fear so grew in me I hither fled, Under the covering of a careful night, Who seem'd my good protector; and, being here, Bethought me what was past, what might succeed. I knew him tyrannous; and tyrants' fears Decrease not, but grow faster than the years: And should he doubt, as no doubt he doth, That I should open to the listening air How many worthy princes' bloods were shed, To keep his bed of blackness unlaid ope, To lop that doubt, he'll fill this land with arms, And make pretence of wrong that I have done him; When all, for mine, if I may call offence, Must feel war's blow, who spares not innocence: Which love to all, of which thyself art one, Who now reprovest me for it,-

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: Alas, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks, Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts How I might stop this tempest ere it came; And finding little comfort to relieve them, I thought it princely charity to grieve them.

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: Well, my lord, since you have given me leave to speak, Freely will I speak. Antiochus you fear, And justly too, I think, you fear the tyrant, Who either by public war or private treason Will take away your life. Therefore, my lord, go travel for a while, Till that his rage and anger be forgot, Or till the Destinies do cut his thread of life. Your rule direct to any; if to me, Day serves not light more faithful than I'll be.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I do not doubt thy faith; But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?

dialogues.speaker: Helcanus
dialogues.line: We'll mingle our bloods together in the earth, From whence we had our being and our birth.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Tyre, I now look from thee then, and to Tarsus Intend my travel, where I'll hear from thee; And by whose letters I'll dispose myself. The care I had and have of subjects' good On thee I lay, whose wisdom's strength can bear it. I'll take thy word for faith, not ask thine oath: Who shuns not to break one will sure crack both: But in our orbs we'll live so round and safe, That time of both this truth shall ne'er convince, Thou show'dst a subject's shine, I a true prince.

scenes.location: Tyre. An ante-chamber in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: So, this is Tyre, and this the court. Here must I kill King Pericles; and if I do it not, I am sure to be hanged at home: 'tis dangerous. Well, I perceive he was a wise fellow, and had good discretion, that, being bid to ask what he would of the king, desired he might know none of his secrets: now do I see he had some reason for't; for if a king bid a man be a villain, he's bound by the indenture of his oath to be one. Husht, here come the lords of Tyre.

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: You shall not need, my fellow peers of Tyre, Further to question me of your king's departure: His seal'd commission, left in trust with me, Doth speak sufficiently he's gone to travel.

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: How? the king gone?

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: If further yet you will be satisfied, Why, as it were unlicensed of your loves, He would depart, I'll give some light unto you. Being at Antioch-

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: What from Antioch?

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: Royal Antiochus-on what cause I know not Took some displeasure at him; at least he judged so: And doubting lest that he had err'd or sinn'd, To show his sorrow, he'd correct himself; So puts himself unto the shipman's toil, With whom each minute threatens life or death.

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: Well, I perceive I shall not be hang'd now, although I would; But since he's gone, the king's seas must please He 'scaped the land, to perish at the sea. I'll present myself. Peace to the lords of Tyre!

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Thaliard
dialogues.line: From him I come With message unto princely Pericles; But since my landing I have understood Your lord has betook himself to unknown travels, My message must return from whence it came.

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: We have no reason to desire it, Commended to our master, not to us: Yet, ere you shall depart, this we desire, As friends to Antioch, we may feast in Tyre.

scenes.location: Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: My Dionyza, shall we rest us here, And by relating tales of others' griefs, See if 'twill teach us to forget our own?

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it; For who digs hills because they do aspire Throws down one mountain to cast up a higher. O my distressed lord, even such our griefs are; Here they're but felt, and seen with mischief's eyes, But like to groves, being topp'd, they higher rise.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: O Dionyza, Who wanteth food, and will not say he wants it, Or can conceal his hunger till he famish? Our tongues and sorrows do sound deep Our woes into the air; our eyes do weep, Till tongues fetch breath that may proclaim them louder; That, if heaven slumber while their creatures want, They may awake their helps to comfort them. I'll then discourse our woes, felt several years, And wanting breath to speak, help me with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: I'll do my best, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: This Tarsus, o'er which I have the government, A city on whom plenty held full hand, For riches strew'd herself even in the streets; Whose towers bore heads so high they kiss'd the clouds, And strangers ne'er beheld but wonder'd at; Whose men and dames so jetted and adorn'd, Like one another's glass to trim them by: Their tables were stored full to glad the sight, And not so much to feed on as delight; All poverty was scorn'd, and pride so great, The name of help grew odious to repeat.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: O, 'tis too true.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: But see what heaven can do! By this our change, These mouths, who but of late, earth, sea, and air, Were all too little to content and please, Although they gave their creatures in abundance, As houses are defiled for want of use, They are now starved for want of exercise: Those palates who, not yet two summers younger, Must have inventions to delight the taste, Would now be glad of bread and beg for it: Those mothers who, to nousle up their babes, Thought nought too curious, are ready now To eat those little darlings whom they loved. So sharp are hunger's teeth, that man and wife Draw lots who first shall die to lengthen life: Here stands a lord, and there a lady weeping; Here many sink, yet those which see them fall Have scarce strength left to give them burial. Is not this true?

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witness it.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: O, let those cities that of plenty's cup And her prosperities so largely taste, With their superflous riots, hear these tears! The misery of Tarsus may be theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Lord
dialogues.line: Where's the lord governor?

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: Here. Speak out thy sorrows which thou bring'st in haste, For comfort is too far for us to expect.

dialogues.speaker: Lord
dialogues.line: We have descried, upon our neighbouring shore, A portly sail of ships make hitherward.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: I thought as much. One sorrow never comes but brings an heir, That may succeed as his inheritor; And so in ours: some neighbouring nation, Taking advantage of our misery, That stuff'd the hollow vessels with their power, To beat us down, the which are down already; And make a conquest of unhappy me, Whereas no glory's got to overcome.

dialogues.speaker: Lord
dialogues.line: That's the least fear; for, by the semblance Of their white flags display'd, they bring us peace, And come to us as favourers, not as foes.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: Thou speak'st like him's untutor'd to repeat: Who makes the fairest show means most deceit. But bring they what they will and what they can, What need we fear? The ground's the lowest, and we are half way there. Go tell their general we attend him here, To know for what he comes, and whence he comes, And what he craves.

dialogues.speaker: Lord
dialogues.line: I go, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: Welcome is peace, if he on peace consist; If wars, we are unable to resist.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Lord governor, for so we hear you are, Let not our ships and number of our men Be like a beacon fired to amaze your eyes. We have heard your miseries as far as Tyre, And seen the desolation of your streets: Nor come we to add sorrow to your tears, But to relieve them of their heavy load; And these our ships, you happily may think Are like the Trojan horse was stuff'd within With bloody veins, expecting overthrow, Are stored with corn to make your needy bread, And give them life whom hunger starved half dead.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: The gods of Greece protect you! And we'll pray for you.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Arise, I pray you, rise: We do not look for reverence, but for love, And harbourage for ourself, our ships and men.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: The which when any shall not gratify, Or pay you with unthankfulness in thought, Be it our wives, our children, or ourselves, The curse of heaven and men succeed their evils! Till when,-the which I hope shall ne'er be seen,- Your grace is welcome to our town and us.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Which welcome we'll accept; feast here awhile, Until our stars that frown lend us a smile.

scenes.location: Pentapolis. An open place by the seaside.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Yet cease your ire, you angry stars of heaven! Wind, rain, and thunder, remember earthly man Is but a substance that must yield to you; And I, as fits my nature, do obey you: Alas, the sea hath cast me on the rocks, Wash'd me from shore to shore, and left me breath Nothing to think on but ensuing death: Let it suffice the greatness of your powers To have bereft a prince of all his fortunes; And having thrown him from your watery grave, Here to have death in peace is all he'll crave.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: What, ho, Pilch!

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Ha, come and bring away the nets!

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: What, Patch-breech, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Third Fisherman
dialogues.line: What say you, master?

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Look how thou stirrest now! Come away, or I'll fetch thee with a wanion.

dialogues.speaker: Third Fisherman
dialogues.line: Faith, master, I am thinking of the poor men that were cast away before us even now.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Alas, poor souls, it grieved my heart to hear what pitiful cries they made to us to help them, when, well-a-day, we could scarce help ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Third Fisherman
dialogues.line: Nay, master, said not I as much when I saw the porpus how he bounced and tumbled? They say they're half fish, half flesh: a plague on them, they ne'er come but I look to be washed. Master, I marvel how the fishes live in the sea.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Why, as men do a-land; the great ones eat up the little ones: I can compare our rich misers to nothing so fitly as to a whale; a' plays and tumbles, driving the poor fry before him, and at last devours them all at a mouthful. Such whales have I heard on o' the land, who never leave gaping till they swallowed the whole parish, church, steeple, bells and all.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: A pretty moral.

dialogues.speaker: Third Fisherman
dialogues.line: But, master, if I had been the sexton, I would have been that day in the belfry.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Why, man?

dialogues.speaker: Third Fisherman
dialogues.line: Because he should have swallowed me too; and when I had been in his belly, I would have kept such a jangling of the bells, that he should never have left, till he cast bells, steeple, church and parish up again. But if the good King Simonides were of my mind,-

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Simonides?

dialogues.speaker: Third Fisherman
dialogues.line: We would purge the land of these drones, that rob the bee of her honey.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: How from the finny subject of the sea These fishers tell the infirmities of men; And from their watery empire recollect All that may men approve or men detect! Peace be at your labour, honest fishermen.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Honest! good fellow, what's that? If it be a day fits you, search out of the calendar, and nobody look after it.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: May see the sea hath cast upon your coast.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: What a drunken knave was the sea to cast thee in our way!

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: A man whom both the waters and the wind, In that vast tennis-court, have made the ball For them to play upon, entreats you pity him; He asks of you, that never used to beg.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: No, friend, cannot you beg? Here's them in our country of Greece gets more with begging than we can do with working.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Canst thou catch any fishes, then?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I never practised it.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Nay, then thou wilt starve, sure; for here's nothing to be got now-a-days, unless thou canst fish for't.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: What I have been I have forgot to know; But what I am, want teaches me to think on: A man throng'd up with cold: my veins are chill, And have no more of life than may suffice To give my tongue that heat to ask your help; Which if you shall refuse, when I am dead, For that I am a man, pray see me buried.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Die quoth-a? Now gods forbid't, and I have a gown here; come, put it on; keep thee warm. Now, afore me, a handsome fellow! Come, thou shalt go home, and we'll have flesh for holidays, fish for fasting-days, and moreo'er puddings and flap-jacks, and thou shalt be welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Hark you, my friend; you said you could not beg?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I did but crave.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: But crave! Then I'll turn craver too, and so I shall 'scape whipping.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Why, are your beggars whipped, then?

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: O, not all, my friend, not all; for if all your beggars were whipped, I would wish no better office than to be beadle. But, master, I'll go draw up the net.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: How well this honest mirth becomes their labour!

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Hark you, sir, do you know where ye are?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Not well.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Why, I'll tell you: this is called Pentapolis, and our King, the good Simonides.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: The good Simonides, do you call him?

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Ay, sir; and he deserves so to be called for his peaceable reign and good government.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: He is a happy king, since he gains from his subjects the name of good government. How far is his court distant from this shore?

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Marry sir, half a day's journey: and I'll tell you, he hath a fair daughter, and tomorrow is her birth-day; and there are princes and knights come from all parts of the world to joust and tourney for her love.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Were my fortunes equal to my desires, I could wish to make one there.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: O, sir, things must be as they may; and what a man cannot get, he may lawfully deal for-his wife's soul.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Help, master, help! here's a fish hangs in the net, like a poor man's right in the law; 'twill hardly come out. Ha! bots on't, 'tis come at last, and 'tis turned to a rusty armour.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: An armour, friends! I pray you, let me see it. Thanks, Fortune, yet, that, after all my crosses, Thou givest me somewhat to repair myself, And though it was mine own, part of my heritage, Which my dead father did bequeath to me, With this strict charge, even as he left his life. â€˜Keep it, my Pericles; it hath been a shield 'Twixt me and death;'-and pointed to this brace;- â€˜For that it saved me, keep it; in like necessity- The which the gods protect thee from!-may defend thee.' It kept where I kept, I so dearly loved it; Till the rough seas, that spares not any man, Took it in rage, though calm'd have given't again: I thank thee for't: my shipwreck now's no ill, Since I have here my father gave in his will.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: What mean you sir?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: To beg of you, kind friends, this coat of worth, For it was sometime target to a king; I know it by this mark. He loved me dearly, And for his sake I wish the having of it; And that you'd guide me to your sovereign court, Where with it I may appear a gentleman; And if that ever my low fortune's better, I'll pay your bounties; till then rest your debtor.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Why, wilt thou tourney for the lady?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I'll show the virtue I have borne in arms.

dialogues.speaker: First Fisherman
dialogues.line: Why, d'ye take it, and the gods give thee good on't!

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: Ay, but hark you, my friend; 'twas we that made up this garment through the rough seams of the waters: there are certain condolements, certain vails. I hope, sir, if you thrive, you'll remember from whence you had them.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Believe't I will. By your furtherance I am clothed in steel; And spite of all the rapture of the sea, This jewel holds his building on my arm: Unto thy value I will mount myself Upon a courser, whose delightful steps Shall make the gazer joy to see him tread. Only, my friend, I yet am unprovided Of a pair of bases.

dialogues.speaker: Second Fisherman
dialogues.line: We'll sure provide: thou shalt have my best gown to make thee a pair; and I'll bring thee to the court myself.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Then honour be but a goal to my will, This day I'll rise, or else add ill to ill.

scenes.location: The same. A public way, or platform leading to the lists. A

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Are the knights ready to begin the triumph?

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: They are, my liege; And stay your coming to present themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Return them, we are ready; and our daughter, In honour of whose birth these triumphs are, Sits here, like beauty's child, whom Nature gat For men to see, and seeing wonder at.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: It pleaseth you, my royal father, to express My commendations great, whose merit's less.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: It's fit it should be so; for princes are A model, which heaven makes like to itself: As jewels lose their glory if neglected, So princes their renowns if not respected. 'Tis now your honour, daughter, to entertain The labour of each knight in his device.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: Which, to preserve mine honour, I'll perform. The first Knight passes by, and his Squire presents his shield to Thaisa.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Who is the first that doth prefer himself?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: A knight of Sparta, my renowned father; And the device he bears upon his shield Is a black Ethiope reaching at the sun: The word, _Lux tua vita mihi._

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: He loves you well that holds his life of you. The second Knight passes by, and his Squire presents his shield to Thaisa. Who is the second that presents himself?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: A prince of Macedon, my royal father; And the device he bears upon his shield Is an arm'd knight that's conquer'd by a lady; The motto thus, in Spanish, _Piu por dulzura que por forza._ The third Knight passes by, and his Squire presents his shield to Thaisa.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: And what's the third?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: The third of Antioch; And his device, a wreath of chivalry; The word, _Me pompae provexit apex._ The fourth Knight passes by, and his Squire presents his shield to Thaisa.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: What is the fourth?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: A burning torch that's turned upside down; The word, _Quod me alit me extinguit._

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Which shows that beauty hath his power and will, Which can as well inflame as it can kill. The fifth Knight passes by, and his Squire presents his shield to Thaisa.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: The fifth, an hand environed with clouds, Holding out gold that's by the touchstone tried; The motto thus, _Sic spectanda fides._ The sixth Knight, Pericles, passes in rusty armour with bases, and unaccompanied. He presents his device directly to Thaisa.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: And what's the sixth and last, the which the knight himself With such a graceful courtesy deliver'd?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: He seems to be a stranger; but his present is A wither'd branch, that's only green at top; The motto, _In hac spe vivo._

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: A pretty moral; From the dejected state wherein he is, He hopes by you his fortunes yet may flourish.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: He had need mean better than his outward show Can any way speak in his just commend; For by his rusty outside he appears To have practised more the whipstock than the lance.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: He well may be a stranger, for he comes To an honour'd triumph strangely furnished.

dialogues.speaker: Third Lord
dialogues.line: And on set purpose let his armour rust Until this day, to scour it in the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Opinion's but a fool, that makes us scan The outward habit by the inward man. But stay, the knights are coming. We will withdraw into the gallery.

scenes.location: The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Knights, To say you're welcome were superfluous. To place upon the volume of your deeds, As in a title-page, your worth in arms, Were more than you expect, or more than's fit, Since every worth in show commends itself. Prepare for mirth, for mirth becomes a feast: You are princes and my guests.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: But you, my knight and guest; To whom this wreath of victory I give, And crown you king of this day's happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: 'Tis more by fortune, lady, than by merit.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Call it by what you will, the day is yours; And here, I hope, is none that envies it. In framing an artist, art hath thus decreed, To make some good, but others to exceed; And you are her labour'd scholar. Come queen of the feast,- For, daughter, so you are,-here take your place: Marshal the rest, as they deserve their grace.

dialogues.speaker: Knights
dialogues.line: We are honour'd much by good Simonides.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Your presence glads our days; honour we love; For who hates honour hates the gods above.

dialogues.speaker: Marshall
dialogues.line: Sir, yonder is your place.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Some other is more fit.

dialogues.speaker: First Knight
dialogues.line: Contend not, sir; for we are gentlemen Have neither in our hearts nor outward eyes Envied the great, nor shall the low despise.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: You are right courteous knights.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Sit, sir, sit. By Jove, I wonder, that is king of thoughts, These cates resist me, he but thought upon.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: By Juno, that is queen of marriage, All viands that I eat do seem unsavoury, Wishing him my meat. Sure, he's a gallant gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: He's but a country gentleman; Has done no more than other knights have done; Has broken a staff or so; so let it pass.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: To me he seems like diamond to glass.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Yon king's to me like to my father's picture, Which tells me in that glory once he was; Had princes sit, like stars, about his throne, And he the sun, for them to reverence; None that beheld him, but, like lesser lights, Did vail their crowns to his supremacy: Where now his son's like a glow-worm in the night, The which hath fire in darkness, none in light: Whereby I see that time's the king of men, He's both their parent, and he is their grave, And gives them what he will, not what they crave.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: What, are you merry, knights?

dialogues.speaker: Knights
dialogues.line: Who can be other in this royal presence?

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Here, with a cup that's stored unto the brim,- As you do love, fill to your mistress' lips,- We drink this health to you.

dialogues.speaker: Knights
dialogues.line: We thank your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Yet pause awhile. Yon knight doth sit too melancholy, As if the entertainment in our court Had not a show might countervail his worth. Note it not you, Thaisa?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: What is't to me, my father?

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: O attend, my daughter: Princes in this should live like gods above, Who freely give to everyone that comes to honour them: And princes not doing so are like to gnats, Which make a sound, but kill'd are wonder'd at. Therefore to make his entrance more sweet, Here, say we drink this standing-bowl of wine to him.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: Alas, my father, it befits not me Unto a stranger knight to be so bold: He may my proffer take for an offence, Since men take women's gifts for impudence.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: How? Do as I bid you, or you'll move me else.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: Now, by the gods, he could not please me better.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: And furthermore tell him, we desire to know of him, Of whence he is, his name and parentage.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: The king my father, sir, has drunk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I thank him.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: Wishing it so much blood unto your life.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I thank both him and you, and pledge him freely.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: And further he desires to know of you, Of whence you are, your name and parentage.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: A gentleman of Tyre; my name, Pericles; My education been in arts and arms; Who, looking for adventures in the world, Was by the rough seas reft of ships and men, And after shipwreck driven upon this shore.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: He thanks your grace; names himself Pericles, A gentleman of Tyre, Who only by misfortune of the seas Bereft of ships and men, cast on this shore.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Now, by the gods, I pity his misfortune, And will awake him from his melancholy. Come, gentlemen, we sit too long on trifles, And waste the time, which looks for other revels. Even in your armours, as you are address'd, Will well become a soldier's dance. I will not have excuse, with saying this, â€˜Loud music is too harsh for ladies' heads' Since they love men in arms as well as beds. So, this was well ask'd, 'twas so well perform'd. Come, sir; here is a lady which wants breathing too: And I have heard you knights of Tyre Are excellent in making ladies trip; And that their measures are as excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: In those that practise them they are, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: O, that's as much as you would be denied Of your fair courtesy. Unclasp, unclasp: Thanks gentlemen, to all; all have done well.  But you the best. Pages and lights to conduct These knights unto their several lodgings.  Yours, sir, we have given order to be next our own.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I am at your grace's pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Princes, it is too late to talk of love; And that's the mark I know you level at: Therefore each one betake him to his rest; Tomorrow all for speeding do their best.

scenes.location: Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: No, Escanes, know this of me, Antiochus from incest lived not free: For which the most high gods not minding longer To withhold the vengeance that they had in store Due to this heinous capital offence, Even in the height and pride of all his glory, When he was seated in a chariot Of an inestimable value, and his daughter with him, A fire from heaven came and shrivell'd up Their bodies, even to loathing, for they so stunk, That all those eyes adored them ere their fall Scorn now their hand should give them burial.

dialogues.speaker: Escanes
dialogues.line: 'Twas very strange

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: And yet but justice; for though this king were great; His greatness was no guard to bar heaven's shaft, But sin had his reward.

dialogues.speaker: Escanes
dialogues.line: 'Tis very true.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: See, not a man in private conference Or council has respect with him but he.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: It shall no longer grieve without reproof.

dialogues.speaker: Third Lord
dialogues.line: And cursed be he that will not second it.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Follow me, then. Lord Helicane, a word.

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: With me? and welcome: happy day, my lords.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Know that our griefs are risen to the top, And now at length they overflow their banks.

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: Your griefs! for what? Wrong not your prince you love.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: Wrong not yourself, then, noble Helicane; But if the prince do live, let us salute him. Or know what ground's made happy by his breath. If in the world he live, we'll seek him out; If in his grave he rest, we'll find him there. We'll be resolved he lives to govern us, Or dead, give's cause to mourn his funeral, And leave us to our free election.

dialogues.speaker: Second Lord
dialogues.line: Whose death's indeed the strongest in our censure: And knowing this kingdom is without a head,- Like goodly buildings left without a roof Soon fall to ruin,-your noble self, That best know how to rule and how to reign, We thus submit unto,-our sovereign.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Live, noble Helicane!

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: For honour's cause, forbear your suffrages: If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear. Take I your wish, I leap into the seas, Where's hourly trouble for a minute's ease. A twelvemonth longer, let me entreat you To forbear the absence of your king; If in which time expired, he not return, I shall with aged patience bear your yoke. But if I cannot win you to this love, Go search like nobles, like noble subjects, And in your search spend your adventurous worth; Whom if you find, and win unto return, You shall like diamonds sit about his crown.

dialogues.speaker: First Lord
dialogues.line: To wisdom he's a fool that will not yield; And since Lord Helicane enjoineth us, We with our travels will endeavour us.

dialogues.speaker: Helicanus
dialogues.line: Then you love us, we you, and we'll clasp hands: When peers thus knit, a kingdom ever stands.

scenes.location: Pentapolis. A room in the palace.

dialogues.speaker: First Knight
dialogues.line: Good morrow to the good Simonides.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Knights, from my daughter this I let you know, That for this twelvemonth she'll not undertake A married life. Her reason to herself is only known, Which yet from her by no means can I get.

dialogues.speaker: Second Knight
dialogues.line: May we not get access to her, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Faith, by no means; she hath so strictly tied Her to her chamber, that 'tis impossible. One twelve moons more she'll wear Diana's livery; This by the eye of Cynthia hath she vow'd, And on her virgin honour will not break it.

dialogues.speaker: Third Knight
dialogues.line: Loath to bid farewell, we take our leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: So, they are well dispatch'd; now to my daughter's letter: She tells me here, she'll wed the stranger knight, Or never more to view nor day nor light. 'Tis well, mistress; your choice agrees with mine; I like that well: nay, how absolute she's in't, Not minding whether I dislike or no! Well, I do commend her choice; And will no longer have it be delay'd. Soft! here he comes: I must dissemble it.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: All fortune to the good Simonides!

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: To you as much. Sir, I am beholding to you For your sweet music this last night: I do Protest my ears were never better fed With such delightful pleasing harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: It is your grace's pleasure to commend; Not my desert.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Sir, you are music's master.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: The worst of all her scholars, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Let me ask you one thing: What do you think of my daughter, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: A most virtuous princess.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: And she is fair too, is she not?

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: As a fair day in summer, wondrous fair.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Sir, my daughter thinks very well of you; Ay, so well, that you must be her master, And she will be your scholar: therefore look to it.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I am unworthy for her schoolmaster.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: She thinks not so; peruse this writing else.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: What's here? A letter, that she loves the knight of Tyre! 'Tis the king's subtlety to have my life. O, seek not to entrap me, gracious lord, A stranger and distressed gentleman, That never aim'd so high to love your daughter, But bent all offices to honour her.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Thou hast bewitch'd my daughter, And thou art a villain.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: By the gods, I have not: Never did thought of mine levy offence; Nor never did my actions yet commence A deed might gain her love or your displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Traitor, thou liest.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Traitor?

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Ay, traitor.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Even in his throat-unless it be the king- That calls me traitor, I return the lie.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Now, by the gods, I do applaud his courage.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: My actions are as noble as my thoughts, That never relish'd of a base descent. I came unto your court for honour's cause, And not to be a rebel to her state; And he that otherwise accounts of me, This sword shall prove he's honour's enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: No? Here comes my daughter, she can witness it.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Then, as you are as virtuous as fair, Resolve your angry father, if my tongue Did e'er solicit, or my hand subscribe To any syllable that made love to you.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: Why, sir, say if you had, Who takes offence at that would make me glad?

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: Yea, mistress, are you so peremptory?  I am glad on't with all my heart.- I'll tame you; I'll bring you in subjection. Will you, not having my consent, Bestow your love and your affections Upon a stranger?  Who, for aught I know May be, nor can I think the contrary, As great in blood as I myself.- Therefore hear you, mistress; either frame Your will to mine, and you, sir, hear you, Either be ruled by me, or I will make you- Man and wife. Nay, come, your hands, And lips must seal it too: and being join'd, I'll thus your hopes destroy; and for further grief, God give you joy! What, are you both pleased?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: Yes, if you love me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Even as my life my blood that fosters it.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: What, are you both agreed?

dialogues.speaker: Both
dialogues.line: Yes, if't please your majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Simonides
dialogues.line: It pleaseth me so well, that I will see you wed; And then with what haste you can, get you to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Thou god of this great vast, rebuke these surges, Which wash both heaven and hell; and thou that hast Upon the winds command, bind them in brass, Having call'd them from the deep! O, still Thy deafening, dreadful thunders; gently quench Thy nimble, sulphurous flashes! O, how, Lychorida, How does my queen? Thou stormest venomously; Wilt thou spit all thyself? The seaman's whistle Is as a whisper in the ears of death, Unheard. Lychorida! - Lucina, O! Divinest patroness, and midwife gentle To those that cry by night, convey thy deity Aboard our dancing boat; make swift the pangs Of my queen's travails! Now, Lychorida!

dialogues.speaker: Lychorida
dialogues.line: Here is a thing too young for such a place, Who, if it had conceit, would die, as I Am like to do: take in your arms this piece Of your dead queen.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: How? how, Lychorida?

dialogues.speaker: Lychorida
dialogues.line: Patience, good sir; do not assist the storm. Here's all that is left living of your queen, A little daughter: for the sake of it, Be manly, and take comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: O you gods! Why do you make us love your goodly gifts, And snatch them straight away? We here below Recall not what we give, and therein may Vie honour with you.

dialogues.speaker: Lychorida
dialogues.line: Patience, good sir. Even for this charge.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Now, mild may be thy life! For a more blustrous birth had never babe: Quiet and gentle thy conditions! for Thou art the rudeliest welcome to this world That ever was prince's child. Happy what follows! Thou hast as chiding a nativity As fire, air, water, earth, and heaven can make, To herald thee from the womb. Even at the first thy loss is more than can Thy portage quit, with all thou canst find here, Now, the good gods throw their best eyes upon't!

dialogues.speaker: First Sailor
dialogues.line: What courage, sir? God save you!

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Courage enough: I do not fear the flaw; It hath done to me the worst. Yet, for the love Of this poor infant, this fresh new sea-farer, I would it would be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: First Sailor
dialogues.line: Slack the bolins there! Thou wilt not, wilt thou? Blow, and split thyself.

dialogues.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogues.line: But sea-room, and the brine and cloudy billow kiss the moon, I care not.

dialogues.speaker: First Sailor
dialogues.line: Sir, your queen must overboard: the sea works high, the wind is loud and will not lie till the ship be cleared of the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: That's your superstition.

dialogues.speaker: First Sailor
dialogues.line: Pardon us, sir; with us at sea it has been still observed; and we are strong in custom. Therefore briefly yield her; for she must overboard straight.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: As you think meet. Most wretched queen!

dialogues.speaker: Lychorida
dialogues.line: Here she lies, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: A terrible childbed hast thou had, my dear; No light, no fire: th'unfriendly elements Forgot thee utterly; nor have I time To give thee hallow'd to thy grave, but straight Must cast thee, scarcely coffin'd, in the ooze; Where, for a monument upon thy bones, And e'er-remaining lamps, the belching whale And humming water must o'erwhelm thy corpse, Lying with simple shells. O Lychorida. Bid Nestor bring me spices, ink and paper, My casket and my jewels; and bid Nicander Bring me the satin coffer: lay the babe Upon the pillow: hie thee, whiles I say A priestly farewell to her: suddenly, woman.

dialogues.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogues.line: Sir, we have a chest beneath the hatches, caulked and bitumed ready.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I thank thee. Mariner, say what coast is this?

dialogues.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogues.line: We are near Tarsus.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Thither, gentle mariner, Alter thy course for Tyre. When canst thou reach it?

dialogues.speaker: Second Sailor
dialogues.line: By break of day, if the wind cease.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: O, make for Tarsus! There will I visit Cleon, for the babe Cannot hold out to Tyrus. There I'll leave it At careful nursing. Go thy ways, good mariner: I'll bring the body presently.

scenes.location: Ephesus. A room in Cerimon's house.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Philemon, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Philemon
dialogues.line: Doth my lord call?

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Get fire and meat for these poor men: 'T has been a turbulent and stormy night.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I have been in many; but such a night as this, Till now, I ne'er endured.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Your master will be dead ere you return; There's nothing can be minister'd to nature That can recover him.  Give this to the 'pothecary, And tell me how it works.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Good morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Good morrow to your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Gentlemen, why do you stir so early?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Sir, our lodgings, standing bleak upon the sea, Shook as the earth did quake; The very principals did seem to rend, And all to topple: pure surprise and fear Made me to quit the house.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: That is the cause we trouble you so early; 'Tis not our husbandry.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: O, you say well.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: But I much marvel that your lordship, having Rich tire about you, should at these early hours Shake off the golden slumber of repose. 'Tis most strange, Nature should be so conversant with pain. Being thereto not compell'd.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: I hold it ever, Virtue and cunning were endowments greater Than nobleness and riches: careless heirs May the two latter darken and expend; But immortality attends the former, Making a man a god. 'Tis known, I ever Have studied physic, through which secret art, By turning o'er authorities, I have, Together with my practice, made familiar To me and to my aid the blest infusions That dwell in vegetives, in metals, stones; And I can speak of the disturbances That nature works, and of her cures; which doth give me A more content in course of true delight Than to be thirsty after tottering honour, Or tie my pleasure up in silken bags, To please the fool and death.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Your honour has through Ephesus pour'd forth Your charity, and hundreds call themselves Your creatures, who by you have been restored: And not your knowledge, your personal pain, but even Your purse, still open, hath built Lord Cerimon Such strong renown as time shall never-

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: So, lift there.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: Sir, even now Did the sea toss upon our shore this chest: 'Tis of some wreck.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Set't down, let's look upon't.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: 'Tis like a coffin, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Whate'er it be, 'Tis wondrous heavy. Wrench it open straight: If the sea's stomach be o'ercharged with gold, 'Tis a good constraint of fortune it belches upon us.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: 'Tis so, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: How close 'tis caulk'd and bitumed! Did the sea cast it up?

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: I never saw so huge a billow, sir, As toss'd it upon shore.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Wrench it open; Soft! it smells most sweetly in my sense.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: A delicate odour.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: As ever hit my nostril. So up with it. O you most potent gods! what's here? a corpse!

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Most strange!

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Shrouded in cloth of state; balm'd and entreasured With full bags of spices! A passport too! Apollo, perfect me in the characters! _Here I give to understand, If e'er this coffin drives a-land, I, King Pericles, have lost This queen, worth all our mundane cost. Who finds her, give her burying; She was the daughter of a king: Besides this treasure for a fee, The gods requite his charity._ If thou livest, Pericles, thou hast a heart That even cracks for woe! This chanced tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Most likely, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Nay, certainly tonight; For look how fresh she looks! They were too rough That threw her in the sea. Make a fire within Fetch hither all my boxes in my closet. Death may usurp on nature many hours, And yet the fire of life kindle again The o'erpress'd spirits. I heard of an Egyptian That had nine hours lain dead, Who was by good appliance recovered. Well said, well said; the fire and cloths. The rough and woeful music that we have, Cause it to sound, beseech you The viol once more: how thou stirr'st, thou block! The music there!-I pray you, give her air. Gentlemen, this queen will live. Nature awakes; a warmth breathes out of her. She hath not been entranced above five hours. See how she 'gins to blow into life's flower again!

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: The heavens, through you, increase our wonder And sets up your fame for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: She is alive; behold, her eyelids, Cases to those heavenly jewels which Pericles hath lost, Begin to part their fringes of bright gold; The diamonds of a most praised water doth appear, To make the world twice rich. Live, and make us weep To hear your fate, fair creature, rare as you seem to be.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: O dear Diana, Where am I? Where's my lord? What world is this?

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Is not this strange?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Most rare.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Hush, my gentle neighbours! Lend me your hands; to the next chamber bear her. Get linen: now this matter must be look'd to, For her relapse is mortal. Come, come; And Aesculapius guide us!

scenes.location: Tarsus. A room in Cleon's house.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Most honour'd Cleon, I must needs be gone; My twelve months are expired, and Tyrus stands In a litigious peace. You and your lady, Take from my heart all thankfulness! The gods Make up the rest upon you!

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: Your shafts of fortune, though they hurt you mortally, Yet glance full wanderingly on us.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: O, your sweet queen! That the strict fates had pleased you had brought her hither, To have bless'd mine eyes with her!

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: We cannot but obey The powers above us. Could I rage and roar As doth the sea she lies in, yet the end Must be as 'tis. My gentle babe Marina, Whom, for she was born at sea, I have named so, Here I charge your charity withal, Leaving her the infant of your care; Beseeching you to give her princely training, That she may be manner'd as she is born.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: Fear not, my lord, but think Your grace, that fed my country with your corn, For which the people's prayers still fall upon you, Must in your child be thought on. If neglection Should therein make me vile, the common body, By you relieved, would force me to my duty: But if to that my nature need a spur, The gods revenge it upon me and mine, To the end of generation!

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I believe you; Your honour and your goodness teach me to't, Without your vows. Till she be married, madam, By bright Diana, whom we honour, all Unscissored shall this hair of mine remain, Though I show ill in't. So I take my leave. Good madam, make me blessed in your care In bringing up my child.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: I have one myself, Who shall not be more dear to my respect Than yours, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: Madam, my thanks and prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: We'll bring your grace e'en to the edge o'the shore, Then give you up to the mask'd Neptune and The gentlest winds of heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Pericles
dialogues.line: I will embrace your offer. Come, dearest madam. O, no tears, Lychorida, no tears. Look to your little mistress, on whose grace You may depend hereafter. Come, my lord.

scenes.location: Ephesus. A room in Cerimon's house.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Madam, this letter, and some certain jewels, Lay with you in your coffer, which are At your command. Know you the character?

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: It is my lord's. That I was shipp'd at sea, I well remember, Even on my groaning time; but whether there Deliver'd, by the holy gods, I cannot rightly say. But since King Pericles, My wedded lord, I ne'er shall see again, A vestal livery will I take me to, And never more have joy.

dialogues.speaker: Cerimon
dialogues.line: Madam, if this you purpose as ye speak, Diana's temple is not distant far, Where you may abide till your date expire. Moreover, if you please, a niece of mine Shall there attend you.

dialogues.speaker: Thaisa
dialogues.line: My recompense is thanks, that's all; Yet my good will is great, though the gift small.

scenes.location: Tarsus. An open place near the seashore.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: Thy oath remember; thou hast sworn to do't: 'Tis but a blow, which never shall be known. Thou canst not do a thing in the world so soon, To yield thee so much profit. Let not conscience, Which is but cold, inflaming love i' thy bosom, Inflame too nicely; nor let pity, which Even women have cast off, melt thee, but be A soldier to thy purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: I will do't; but yet she is a goodly creature.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: The fitter, then, the gods should have her. Here she comes weeping for her only mistress' death. Thou art resolved?

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: I am resolved.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: No, I will rob Tellus of her weed To strew thy green with flowers: the yellows, blues, The purple violets, and marigolds, Shall as a carpet hang upon thy grave, While summer days do last. Ay me! poor maid, Born in a tempest, when my mother died, This world to me is like a lasting storm, Whirring me from my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: How now, Marina! why do you keep alone? How chance my daughter is not with you? Do not consume your blood with sorrowing; Have you a nurse of me? Lord, how your favour's Changed with this unprofitable woe! Come, give me your flowers, ere the sea mar it. Walk with Leonine; the air is quick there, And it pierces and sharpens the stomach. Come, Leonine, take her by the arm, walk with her.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: No, I pray you; I'll not bereave you of your servant.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: Come, come; I love the king your father, and yourself, With more than foreign heart. We every day Expect him here: when he shall come and find Our paragon to all reports thus blasted, He will repent the breadth of his great voyage; Blame both my lord and me, that we have taken No care to your best courses. Go, I pray you, Walk, and be cheerful once again; reserve That excellent complexion, which did steal The eyes of young and old. Care not for me; I can go home alone.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: Well, I will go; But yet I have no desire to it.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: Come, come, I know 'tis good for you. Walk half an hour, Leonine, at the least: Remember what I have said.

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: I warrant you, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: I'll leave you, my sweet lady, for a while: Pray, walk softly, do not heat your blood: What! I must have a care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: My thanks, sweet madam. Is this wind westerly that blows?

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: South-west.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: When I was born the wind was north.

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: Was't so?

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: My father, as nurse said, did never fear, But cried â€˜Good seamen!' to the sailors, Galling his kingly hands, haling ropes; And clasping to the mast, endured a sea That almost burst the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: When was this?

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: When I was born: Never was waves nor wind more violent; And from the ladder tackle washes off A canvas-climber. â€˜Ha!' says one, â€˜wolt out?' And with a dropping industry they skip From stem to stern: the boatswain whistles, and The master calls and trebles their confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: Come, say your prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: What mean you?

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: If you require a little space for prayer, I grant it: pray; but be not tedious, For the gods are quick of ear, and I am sworn To do my work with haste.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: Why will you kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: To satisfy my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: Why would she have me kill'd now? As I can remember, by my troth, I never did her hurt in all my life: I never spake bad word, nor did ill turn To any living creature: believe me, la, I never kill'd a mouse, nor hurt a fly: I trod upon a worm against my will, But I wept for it. How have I offended, Wherein my death might yield her any profit, Or my life imply her any danger?

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: My commission Is not to reason of the deed, but do it.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: You will not do't for all the world, I hope. You are well favour'd, and your looks foreshow You have a gentle heart. I saw you lately, When you caught hurt in parting two that fought: Good sooth, it show'd well in you: do so now: Your lady seeks my life; come you between, And save poor me, the weaker.

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: I am sworn, And will dispatch.

dialogues.speaker: First Pirate
dialogues.line: Hold, villain!

dialogues.speaker: Second Pirate
dialogues.line: A prize! a prize!

dialogues.speaker: Third Pirate
dialogues.line: Half part, mates, half part, Come, let's have her aboard suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Leonine
dialogues.line: These roguing thieves serve the great pirate Valdes; And they have seized Marina. Let her go: There's no hope she will return. I'll swear she's dead And thrown into the sea. But I'll see further: Perhaps they will but please themselves upon her, Not carry her aboard. If she remain, Whom they have ravish'd must by me be slain.

scenes.location: Mytilene. A room in a brothel.

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: Boult!

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: Search the market narrowly; Mytilene is full of gallants. We lost too much money this mart by being too wenchless.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: We were never so much out of creatures. We have but poor three, and they can do no more than they can do; and they with continual action are even as good as rotten.

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: Therefore let's have fresh ones, whate'er we pay for them. If there be not a conscience to be used in every trade, we shall never prosper.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Thou sayest true: 'tis not our bringing up of poor bastards,-as, I think, I have brought up some eleven-

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Ay, to eleven; and brought them down again. But shall I search the market?

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: What else, man? The stuff we have, a strong wind will blow it to pieces, they are so pitifully sodden.

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: Thou sayest true; they're too unwholesome, o' conscience. The poor Transylvanian is dead, that lay with the little baggage.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Ay, she quickly pooped him; she made him roast-meat for worms. But I'll go search the market.

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: Three or four thousand chequins were as pretty a proportion to live quietly, and so give over.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Why to give over, I pray you? Is it a shame to get when we are old?

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: O, our credit comes not in like the commodity, nor the commodity wages not with the danger: therefore, if in our youths we could pick up some pretty estate, 'twere not amiss to keep our door hatched. Besides, the sore terms we stand upon with the gods will be strong with us for giving over.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Come, others sorts offend as well as we.

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: As well as we! ay, and better too; we offend worse. Neither is our profession any trade; it's no calling. But here comes Boult.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Come your ways. My masters, you say she's a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: First Pirate
dialogues.line: O sir, we doubt it not.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Master, I have gone through for this piece, you see: if you like her, so; if not, I have lost my earnest.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Boult, has she any qualities?

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: She has a good face, speaks well and has excellent good clothes: there's no farther necessity of qualities can make her be refused.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: What is her price, Boult?

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: I cannot be baited one doit of a thousand pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Pandar
dialogues.line: Well, follow me, my masters, you shall have your money presently. Wife, take her in; instruct her what she has to do, that she may not be raw in her entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Boult, take you the marks of her, the colour of her hair, complexion, height, her age, with warrant of her virginity; and cry â€˜He that will give most shall have her first.' Such a maidenhead were no cheap thing, if men were as they have been. Get this done as I command you.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Performance shall follow.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: Alack that Leonine was so slack, so slow! He should have struck, not spoke; or that these pirates, Not enough barbarous, had not o'erboard thrown me For to seek my mother!

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Why lament you, pretty one?

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: That I am pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Come, the gods have done their part in you.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: I accuse them not.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: You are light into my hands, where you are like to live.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: The more my fault To scape his hands where I was like to die.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Ay, and you shall live in pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Yes, indeed shall you, and taste gentlemen of all fashions: you shall fare well; you shall have the difference of all complexions. What! do you stop your ears?

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: Are you a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: What would you have me be, an I be not a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: An honest woman, or not a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Marry, whip the gosling: I think I shall have something to do with you. Come, you're a young foolish sapling, and must be bowed as I would have you.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: The gods defend me!

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: If it please the gods to defend you by men, then men must comfort you, men must feed you, men stir you up. Boult's returned. Now, sir, hast thou cried her through the market?

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: I have cried her almost to the number of her hairs; I have drawn her picture with my voice.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find the inclination of the people, especially of the younger sort?

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Faith, they listened to me as they would have hearkened to their father's testament. There was a Spaniard's mouth so watered, that he went to bed to her very description.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: We shall have him here tomorrow with his best ruff on.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Tonight, tonight. But, mistress, do you know the French knight that cowers i' the hams?

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Who, Monsieur Veroles?

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Ay, he: he offered to cut a caper at the proclamation; but he made a groan at it, and swore he would see her tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Well, well, as for him, he brought his disease hither: here he does but repair it. I know he will come in our shadow, to scatter his crowns in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Well, if we had of every nation a traveller, we should lodge them with this sign.  Pray you, come hither awhile. You have fortunes coming upon you. Mark me: you must seem to do that fearfully which you commit willingly, despise profit where you have most gain. To weep that you live as ye do makes pity in your lovers: seldom but that pity begets you a good opinion, and that opinion a mere profit.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: I understand you not.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: O, take her home, mistress, take her home: these blushes of hers must be quenched with some present practice.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Thou sayest true, i'faith so they must; for your bride goes to that with shame which is her way to go with warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Faith, some do and some do not. But, mistress, if I have bargained for the joint,-

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Thou mayst cut a morsel off the spit.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: I may so. BAWD. Who should deny it? Come young one, I like the manner of your garments well.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: Ay, by my faith, they shall not be changed yet.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Boult, spend thou that in the town: report what a sojourner we have; you'll lose nothing by custom. When nature framed this piece, she meant thee a good turn; therefore say what a paragon she is, and thou hast the harvest out of thine own report.

dialogues.speaker: Boult
dialogues.line: I warrant you, mistress, thunder shall not so awake the beds of eels as my giving out her beauty stirs up the lewdly inclined. I'll bring home some tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Come your ways; follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Marina
dialogues.line: If fires be hot, knives sharp, or waters deep, Untied I still my virgin knot will keep. Diana, aid my purpose!

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: What have we to do with Diana? Pray you, will you go with us?

scenes.location: Tarsus. A room in Cleon's house.

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: Why, are you foolish? Can it be undone?

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: O, Dionyza, such a piece of slaughter The sun and moon ne'er look'd upon!

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: I think you'll turn a child again.

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
dialogues.line: Were I chief lord of all this spacious world, I'd give it to undo the deed. A lady, Much less in blood than virtue, yet a princess To equal any single crown o' the earth I' the justice of compare! O villain Leonine! Whom thou hast poison'd too: If thou hadst drunk to him, 't had been a kindness Becoming well thy face. What canst thou say When noble Pericles shall demand his child?

dialogues.speaker: Dionyza
dialogues.line: That she is dead. Nurses are not the fates, To foster it, nor ever to preserve. She died at night; I'll say so. Who can cross it? Unless you play the pious innocent, And for an honest attribute cry out â€˜She died by foul play.'

dialogues.speaker: Cleon
